prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Binaries
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 7 continuum observations to separately detect circumprimary and circumsecondary disks around 26 binaries in ChaI.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Observations are optimized for continuum observations. In order achieve the science goals presented in the science case we propose to reach an rms-noise level of 0.2 mJy/beam at 0.87 mm. This is to ensure that we can expect a high detection fraction >0.5, as demonstrated in Fig. 1 (right) of the science case. This requires ~1.8 min of on-source time per target, adding up to 2.2 hours to observe all 26 binaries (including overheads, using the ALMA OT). Compared with our recent APEX observations of these systems, the proposed ALMA observations are more sensitive by a factor of ~30 at the same wavelength (see Table 1). Line observations with the integration times determined by the continuum sensitivity lead to a S/N>3 for lines >90mJy/beam, values that are frequently exhibited by protoplanetary systems.

We propose to use Band 7 because it is the ALMA band which is most sensitive to circumstellar dust continuum emission while providing the required angular resolution to reach all science goals. Basebands of width 1875MHz were placed as well as possible outside atmospheric absorption features to maximize continuum sensitivity. One baseband was set to smaller channel spacing (468.7MHz) to increase the velocity resolution to 0.2 km/s, allowing us to serendipitously search for molecular line emission in the 12CO(3-2) band while not significantly decreasing the overall continuum sensitivity. As some of the target stars show active accretion, detection of this line is likely in part of the targeted sample and the study of the gas kinematics will be an important bonus of our program. We will use dual polarization to maximize sensitivity.

* Angular Resolution. An essential part of the science case (Sect. 2.3) is the observation of individual components of binary stars with minimum separations of 0.12". The requested angular resolution is required to resolve these small separations.
* Largest Angular Scale. Part of the science case foresees measuring the masses and sizees of circumstellar disks, which require us to spatially resolve all relevant scales. Diameters of disks range up to ~500 AU, which is equivalent to ~3.5" at the distance of the targets of ~160pc.
The choice of angular resolution and largest angular scale require two array configurations, an extended one providing a spatial resolution of 0.10", and a more compact configuration to cover scales up to ~3.5". Use of the ACA is not required.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Stars frequently form in binary systems. Our observational knowledge about the evolution of protoplanetary disks in binary stars, however, currently leaves many questions unanswered. For example, while theory predicts how the sizes of circumstellar disks are truncated in the presence of a binary companion, an observational confirmation is still required. We propose to acquire high-angular resolution band 7 continuum observations of 26 binary stars in the Chamaeleon I star-forming region. The inferred disk masses and sizes will be correlated with stellar and binary parameters from our extensive near-IR binary investigations of the target sample. This is the first study dedicated to measuring the correlation of hot inner disk material and cold outer dust around binary star components to investigate whether the evolution of a truncated binary star disk is significantly different from that of singles. It will more than double the current amount of data to test the theoretically predicted truncation radii of disks in binaries, with many applications in the fields of star and planet formation. This is a re-submission of a previously successful (but un-observed) cycle 2 proposal.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
